Detailed Description

template<typename TYPE>
class Moo::Image< TYPE >

This class is a general in-memory image class.

You can also wrap raw pointers as an image (e.g. DirectX textures).

template<typename TYPE>
Moo::Image< TYPE >::Image ( uint32  w,
uint32  h,
PixelType *  pixels,
bool  owns = true,
size_t  stride = 0,
bool  flipped = false,
std::string const &  allocator = "unknown image" 
) [inline]

This constructor allows for pretending an existing bit of memory is an image.

Parameters:
w The width of the image.
h The height of the image.
pixels The image's pixels from left to right, top to bottom.
owns If true then the pixels are deleted in the destructor, if false then the pixels are left alone.
stride The distance between lines in bytes. If zero then this will be sizeof(PixelType)*w.
flipped If true then the image is flipped in the y-direction (e.g. like a Windows DIB section).
allocator A string describing the allocator of this object.

other The image to copy from.

void Moo::Image< TYPE >::blit ( Image< TYPE > const &  other,
uint32  srcX = 0,
uint32  srcY = 0,
uint32  srcW = (uint32)-1,
uint32  srcH = (uint32)-1,
int32  dstX = 0,
int32  dstY = 0 
) [inline]

Copy from a sub-image.

We assume that the coordinates in the sub-image are valid. We clip in the destination image.

Parameters:
other Source Image to copy from.
srcX The source x coordinate.
srcY The source y coordinate.
srcW The source width, if -1 then the source's width is used.
srcH The source height if -1 then the source's height is used.
dstX The destination x coordinate.
dstY The destination y coordinate.

template<typename TYPE>
double Moo::Image< TYPE >::getBicubic ( double  x,
double  y 
) const [inline]

This safely gets the value of a pixel at (x, y) using bicubic interpolation.

Safe means boundary clamping wrapping conditions. It assumes that you can multiply a pixel by a scalar and add pixels to interpolate them.

This returns double as a hack. It's needed for extra precision in terrain import. To get rid of it we should define a traits class that can be used to override the return type of this and the float version.

Parameters:
x The x coordinate.
y The y coordinate.
Returns:
The value of the image at (x, y).

template<typename TYPE>
Image< TYPE >::PixelType Moo::Image< TYPE >::getBicubic ( float  x,
float  y 
) const [inline]

This safely gets the value of a pixel at (x, y) using bicubic interpolation.

Safe means boundary clamping wrapping conditions. It assumes that you can multiply a pixel by a scalar and add pixels to interpolate them.

Parameters:
x The x coordinate.
y The y coordinate.
Returns:
The value of the image at (x, y).

template<typename TYPE>
Image< TYPE >::PixelType Moo::Image< TYPE >::getBilinear ( float  x,
float  y 
) const [inline]

This safely gets the value of a pixel at (x, y) using bilinear interpolation.

Safe means boundary clamping wrapping conditions. It assumes that you can multiply a pixel by a scalar and add pixels to interpolate them.

Parameters:
x The x coordinate.
y The y coordinate.
Returns:
The bilinear value at (x, y) using clamping wrapping conditions.

template<typename TYPE>
TYPE * Moo::Image< TYPE >::getRow ( uint32  y  )  [inline]

This function returns the address of the first elevation value in the given row.

Elevation values in the row are guaranteed to be linearly accessible from this pixel.

Parameters:
y The y coordinate of the row to get.
Returns:
The address of the first pixel in row y.

Returns:

template<typename TYPE>
void Moo::Image< TYPE >::init ( uint32  w,
uint32  h,
PixelType *  pixels,
bool  owns,
size_t  stride,
bool  flipped 
) [protected]

This initialises the image with raw data.

It should only be used by derived classes where the image wraps some structure other than memory allocated by new.

Parameters:
w The new width.
h The new height.
pixels The new pixel data.
owns Does the image delete pixels in the dtor?
stride The distance between lines in bytes. If zero then this will be sizeof(pixels)*w.
flipped If true then the image is flipped in the y-direction (e.g. like a Windows DIB section).

template<typename TYPE>
size_t Moo::Image< TYPE >::rawDataSize (  )  const [inline]

This method returns how much raw memory would be needed to copy the image's data to/from memory.

It does not include overhead such as member variables size. In practice the amount of memory used internally by the image class can be larger since you can set an arbitrary stride. This is the size of the contiguousMemoryBuffer used in the copyTo and copyFrom methods.

Returns:
The amount of memory that the image would take if it was stored as a contiguous buffer.

template<typename TYPE>
size_t Moo::Image< TYPE >::rawRowSize (  )  const

This method returns how much memory is used by one row of data.

This will be greater than or equal to sizeof(PixelType)*width(), since we allow arbitrary strides.

Returns:
The number of bytes that is needed to store one row.

template<typename TYPE>
void Moo::Image< TYPE >::resize ( uint32  w,
uint32  h,
PixelType *  pixels,
bool  owns,
size_t  stride = 0,
bool  flipped = false 
) [inline]

Resize the underlying image.

Existing pixels are not preserved.

h The new height.

stride The distance between lines in bytes. If zero then this will be sizeof(PixelType)*w.
flipped If true then the image is flipped in the y-direction (e.g. like a Windows DIB section).

This safely sets the value of a pixel at (x, y).

Safe means if x or y are outside the valid range then nothing is done.

y The y coordinate.
value The value to assign to the specified co-ordinates.
